title: Pidato #GameofThrones Jokowi Tuai Pujian
body:
Pidato #GameofThrones Jokowi Tuai Pujian

[ad_1]

summary: [SPOILERS] What was the narrative explanation for this scene
title: [SPOILERS] What was the narrative explanation for this scene
body:
Reposted as I made a mistake with the title:

I’ve skirted around this question before but i wanted to address from a purely technical point of view. The scene i’m wondering about is when Dany rescues the wight-hunting party from the frozen lake beyond the wall. Jon can’t escape with them and falls into the water being left behind. Jon then escapes with Benjen’s help before being reunited with Dany by the end of the episode.

My problem with this is that it seems entirely superfluous, the only consequence we’re shown is that Benjen sacrifices himself to help Jon escape, that is the only thing that would be different compared to Jon being rescued with everyone else by Dany.

Chekhov’s Gun is a narrative principle that states every part of a story has to have a purpose (if you see a gun hanging on the wall early in the story, that gun has to be fired before the end). Jon being left behind appears to serve no narrative purpose.

Therefore there are four considerations to make:

  1. There is a narrative purpose that has simply gone over my head.
  2. It was bad story telling, the show runners just wanted to add some inconsequential drama.
  3. There is something significant to Benjen’s death.
  4. Something happened whilst Jon was alone that we are not yet aware of which will have consequences in season 8.

I’ve often suspected that Jon will not complete a traditional ‘Hero’s Jouney arc’, he is the most traditional hero figure in a very non-traditional story and I think GRRM will look to subvert expectations for him. I therefore have a strong suspicion that point 4 has some merit, what I don’t know is what the consequences of him being left behind will be. Anyone have any thoughts.



Source: https://ift.tt/2NDx2mv

title: [SPOILERS] The Hound
body:
So I’m all caught up and just finished watching S7 Ep7. But I kept wondering about the hound and how did he come back. After the fight with Brianne. Arya finds him wounded and she doesn’t kill him but just leaves him to die. But then he comes back a few episodes later. I think I might have missed something here?



Source: https://ift.tt/2OWCzsM

summary: [SPOILERS] What was the narrative reason that Jon was left behind by Dany beyond the wall?
title: [SPOILERS] What was the narrative reason that Jon was left behind by Dany beyond the wall?
body:
I’ve skirted around this question before but i wanted to address from a purely technical point of view. The scene i’m wondering about is when Dany rescues the wight-hunting party from the frozen lake beyond the wall. Jon can’t escape with them and falls into the water being left behind. Jon then escapes with Benjen’s help before being reunited with Dany by the end of the episode.

My problem with this is that it seems entirely superfluous, the only consequence we’re shown is that Benjen sacrifices himself to help Jon escape, that is the only thing that would be different compared to Jon being rescued with everyone else by Dany.

Chekhov’s Gun is a narrative principle that states every part of a story has to have a purpose (if you see a gun hanging on the wall early in the story, that gun has to be fired before the end). Jon being left behind appears to serve no narrative purpose.

Therefore there are four considerations to make:

  1. There is a narrative purpose that has simply gone over my head.
  2. It was bad story telling, the show runners just wanted to add some inconsequential drama.
  3. There is something significant to Benjen’s death.
  4. Something happened whilst Jon was alone that we are not yet aware of which will have consequences in season 8.

I’ve often suspected that Jon will not complete a traditional ‘Hero’s Jouney arc’, he is the most traditional hero figure in a very non-traditional story and I think GRRM will look to subvert expectations for him. I therefore have a strong suspicion that point 4 has some merit, what I don’t know is what the consequences of him being left behind will be. Anyone have any thoughts.



Source: https://ift.tt/2IQWc05

summary: There’s so much pure dumbassery on GoT that I kinda wonder how the writers get away with it. On a show with such a huge audience...
body:
There’s so much pure dumbassery on GoT that I kinda wonder how the writers get away with it. On a show with such a huge audience and budget you’d think they’d hold the writers’ feet to the fire about such things as plot holes and ooc moments. I know that if I financed that kind of show I would want the end product to be absolutely perfect. Yet you have things like “Arya gets stabbed in the gut three times and recovers within a day” or “A horde of Dothraki manage to sneak up on the Lannister army” or “Sansa doesn’t tell Jon about the extra army she called (because dramatic tension?)” or “Everything Littlefinger has done over the last three seasons”. It’s baffling.

And I mean, the show is still hugely enjoyable, mostly because the characters are so vivid and well-rounded, the world feels very alive, JRRM is really good at naming stuff… and the beautiful costumes, the tons of background lore. It’s very good, don’t get me wrong, but that makes it all the more surprising that there are such obvious and, I think, easy to fix plot holes. It’s strange that out of all things the story is its Achilles heel.
